Entries.default: Color flushes his cheeks.
"Think a bookish lad like ye can feign dull? He's stewing on the fish-scaled one." Iselmyr's voice is high with exasperation.
"Fye, for the days when a bashing fixed all." She sounds uncharacteristically tired.
"Anyway, it does seem Tekēhu and I have gotten off on the wrong foot."
"Small wonder I was a terrible spy. Am I truly so obvious?" He shakes his head, seemingly to himself.
Suddenly, a look of aggravation flickers through his face. His features contort into a fiendish parody of themselves.
"What's your problem with Tekēhu?"
"We're all in this together! I can't have my crew divided by petty grudges."
"Whatever your feelings, you need to put them aside and work with him."

"Where to begin?"

He rolls his eyes.

Aloth is leafing through his grimoire, his fingers tracing familiar shapes along its pages while his lips silently recite spells and incantations.

He snaps the grimoire shut as you approach.
"He thinks some skill with water and a head of tentacles make him Ondra's blessing on land."
His face contorts again. "Fye, there's some kindness in the gods to give us such a spectacle." Iselmyr twists Aloth's lips in a brief smile.
He clears his throat. "I'm certain he's a perfectly good entertainer, but I have my doubts about his reliability." He folds his arms.

"It isn't that. It's just..."

He rolls his eyes.

"Of course. But..."

He rolls his eyes.
"He's traveling new territory with a bunch of strangers. He'll adjust."
"He's loud and boastful, and you don't like that."
"So he's naive. That comes with being young."
"Enough about Tekēhu."
"Well, of course not."
"I should hope so."
"Anyway, you did."
"That's very different from your experiences growing up."
"Remind you of Iselmyr?"
"And completely sheltered and coddled."
He hesitates, momentarily caught off-guard.
"Fye, nae half so pretty."
"We certainly agree on that much." He smirks.
"I apologize for any... unseemliness on my part. This won't become a problem, [Player Name]. I promise."
"Speak plainly with me, Aloth. We won't get anywhere mincing words."
"You're clearly distressed. Perhaps talking it through would help."
"That's hardly the same." He swallows back another look of irritation.

"Please, [Player Name]. Iselmyr may be uncouth, but at least she has some mettle."

He swallows back another look of irritation.

"Please, [Player Name]. Iselmyr may have been uncouth, but at least she had some mettle."

He swallows back another look of irritation.
He hesitates, momentarily caught off-guard.
"Perhaps not, but I hardly see what that has to do with anything." He bristles, drawing his shoulders straighter and tugging at his sleeves.

"[Player Name]. I was hoping you'd have a moment to talk."

He swallows, pressing his lips into a grim, determined line.
"I continue to have concerns about Tekēhu."
"What is it now?"
"I have concerns that you continue to bring this up!"
"I can't change him. You might as well learn to live with him."
"Enough! I'm sick of your bad attitude, Aloth."

His eyes widen, and his face goes a shade paler.

But his mouth remains firm, his jaw set.
"It isn't my attitude that should worry you."
He shakes his head impatiently.
"We've traveled together across two countries. Fought vengeful gods and their immortal servants."
"Did I question you when you dispersed thousands of souls into oblivion?"
"Did I question you when you fed thousands of souls to Woedica, the architect of so much misery?"
"Did I question you when you scattered thousands of souls like so much chaff on the wind?"
"Did I question you when you left Gilded Vale under the rule of a madman?"

"Did I question you when you left Dyrford in the grips of a bloodthirsty cult?

"Or when you sent that poor girl back to her uncle?"
"It seems as though this is all a diversion to him. One he'll happily abandon for more bathhouse revels once the mood seizes him."
"I don't begrudge him his merriment, but I don't trust him to stand by us when things get difficult, either."
"He'll come through for us. Give him a chance."
"Ha! And how many fights have you spent on the floor?"
"Neither do I, so I'm keeping an eye on him."
"We don't know what anyone's made of until true tests arise. It's the same for Tekēhu."
"He barely feels any sense of duty toward his own people. What makes you think he'll stand by you?"
"He thinks a head full of tentacles and delusions qualifies him for leadership! How can you trust him?"
"I've seen his type before. No sense of loyalty or responsibility. No belief in any ends beyond his own."
"I knew students like him at Bragganhyl, in Aedyr. Pampered creatures who didn't believe in peril because they had never known it."
"The point is, he's untested and yet he plays with great power. He's a liability, [Player Name]."
"A chance?"
"I know you've grown... attached. And that's what worries me."
"You came around. You went from being a Leaden Key spy to a dependable ally."
"Tekēhu's young and confused. He just needs time and experience."
"He's been under the guild's thumb for most of his life. He's got a lot to decide for himself."
"He's a member of this crew, nothing more. I don't have to trust him beyond that."
"...As long as you're clear about it." He looks at you doubtfully.
"As one of Ondra's godlike, he bears a great burden for the Huana. He's figuring out what that means."
"You weren't exactly leadership material when we first met. But you came around."
"That's the problem."
"Please, hear me out now."
"He's still a part of this crew."
"I suppose you're right. I shall do my best to see that he does not bring us trouble."
"That was quite different." He stiffens and glances away, but not before you catch a look of conviction in his eye.
"Whether you want to admit it or not, he reminds you of yourself five years ago. And that bothers you."

"Anyway, I suppose you've made your point. And perhaps I've been uncharitable with him.

"I shall try to do better."
"You've made your point. I don't want to hear it again."
"Don't worry, I won't trouble you further." He gives you a shrewd look.
"I don't owe you an explanation, Aloth."
"Perhaps he won't. I can't pretend that his priorities are perfectly aligned with mine."
"Perhaps I can't. I won't pretend that his priorities are perfectly aligned with mine."
He shakes his head.
"And ye've me to thank it's nye more!"
He clears his throat. "That's hardly the point."

He nods. "I think that's wise."

He sighs.
"I shall do my best to see that he does not bring us trouble."
"Iselmyr, your explosive temper creates as many problems as it solves. You just don't stick around for the aftermath."
"D'ye think his trunk is always wet, or does it just shine so? Suppose the rest of his hair is squirmy, even the parts-"

"Until they toyed with animancy."

He grows distant and silent.
